page.title: 02Ecology
page.content: In this block bordered by four roads only one of which A32 bears any heavy traffic the arable and parkland (which is preserved for game) and woodland to the south(where the Foresty Commission grows the only Southern Beech Notho- fagus Procera in South England) support wildlife including deer,hares which are now not so plentiful. Birds to be found in the hedges bordering the footpaths include sparrowhawks and owls also kestrels and plovers on the higher grasslands. Such undisturbed habitat supports insects and butter- flies first the Orange Tips and Brim- stones then the Ringlets,Speckled Wood Blues, with a few Marbled Whites but not in colonies, Painted Ladies and occsionally flying high amongst the oaks the shy and resplendent Purple Emperor butterfly.
